title: Frederick VI, Landgrave of Hesse-Homburg
text:
Frederick VI (30 July 1769 – 2 April 1829) reigned as <a href="List%20of%20rulers%20of%20Hesse%23Landgraves%20of%20Hesse-Homburg%2C%201622%E2%80%931866">Landgrave of Hesse-Homburg</a> from 1820 until his death in 1829.
Biography.
Born in Homburg, <a href="Hesse">Hesse</a>, on 30 July 1769, Friedrich Joseph Ludwig Carl August was the eldest son of the incumbent <a href="Landgrave">Landgrave</a> of <a href="Hesse-Homburg">Hesse-Homburg</a>, <a href="Frederick%20V%2C%20Landgrave%20of%20Hesse-Homburg">Frederick V</a>, and his wife <a href="Caroline%20of%20Hesse-Darmstadt">Caroline of Hesse-Darmstadt</a>, the eldest child of the then Landgrave of <a href="Hesse-Darmstadt">Hesse-Darmstadt</a>, <a href="Louis%20IX%2C%20Landgrave%20of%20Hesse-Darmstadt">Louis IX</a>.
Frederick was appointed a captain of the Russian cavalry in 1783 and was made an Austrian general during the <a href="Napoleonic%20Wars">Great French War</a>. For his services in that conflict, he was created a Commander of the Austrian <a href="Military%20Order%20of%20Maria%20Theresa">Military Order of Maria Theresa</a>.
Despite the vocal objections of her mother, <a href="Charlotte%20of%20Mecklenburg-Strelitz">Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz</a>, Frederick married <a href="Princess%20Elizabeth%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Princess Elizabeth of the United Kingdom</a>, the third daughter of King <a href="George%20III%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">George III</a>, in the Queen's House in the Mall (now integrated into <a href="Buckingham%20Palace">Buckingham Palace</a>) on 7 April 1818. It was no love match: Elizabeth longed to be free from her domineering mother at any cost, while Frederick needed her sizeable dowry to improve the <a href="Landgraviate">Landgraviate</a>'s strained finances. As Elizabeth was over the age of 48 at the time of their marriage, this union produced no offspring.
Landgrave Frederick V died on 20 January 1820; Frederick succeeded him as monarch of the principality. The new Landgrave struggled to repay his father's exorbitant debts. Nine years into his reign, the Landgrave died of complications from a pre-existing leg wound. He was succeeded by his brother, <a href="Louis%20William%2C%20Landgrave%20of%20Hesse-Homburg">Louis William</a>.
Citations.
